document.docTitle: Three new species and one new record of Tullbergiidae (Collembola: Onychiuroidea) from Tierra del Fuego

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Three new species and one new record of Tullbergiidae (Collembola: Onychiuroidea) from Tierra del Fuego

emphasis.docTitle: Three new species and one new record of Tullbergiidae ( Collembola : Onychiuroidea) from Tierra del Fuego

paragraph.emphasis: C/ Ría de Solía 3 , ch. 39, 39610 El Astillero ( Spain ). E-mail: jarbeapo@gmail.com

subSection.paragraph:
Three new species,
Tullbergia rapoporti
sp. nov.
,
Dinaphorura nerudai
sp. nov.
and
Dinaphorura najtae
sp. nov.
, and one new record,
Tullbergia meridionalis Cassagnau & Rapoport, 1962
are described based on specimens from Tierra del Fuego.
Tullbergia rapoporti
sp. nov.
is similar to
T. crozetensis
, but can be distinguished from it by the presence of an empodial appendage and the chaetotaxy of Abd VI.
Dinaphorura nerudai
sp. nov.
is diagnosed by the dorsal pso formula, the seven spiniform processes on Abd VI, an elongate PAO, the absence of vesicle on Ant IV and the dorsal chaetotaxy.
Dinaphorura najtae
sp. nov.
is characterised by the dorsal pso formula, the seven spiniform processes on Abd VI, a triangular PAO, the absence of vesicle on Ant IV and the dorsal chaetotaxy.

Key words : taxonomy, chaetotaxy,
Tullbergia
,
Dinaphorura ,
southern South America

The family Tullbergiidae has a world-wide distribution and currently comprises thirty-two genera and 221 species (Bellinger et al.
1996–2015
). This family is represented in Tierra del Fuego by seven described species in only two genera:
Tullbergia bisetosa Börner, 1903
,
T. insularis Wahlgren, 1906
,
T. quadrisetosa (Willem, 1902 )
,
T. trisetosa (Schäffer, 1897 )
,
Dinaphorura americana Rapoport, 1962
,
D. magellanica Rubio, 1974
and
D. spinosissima (Wahlgren, 1906 )
. In the present paper, one new species of
Tullbergia
and two new species of
Dinaphorura
are described. Specimens of
Tullbergia meridionalis Cassagnau & Rapoport, 1962
are also described, which are recorded for the first time in the Tierra del Fuego region. These species were found among an abundant material of Collembola collected in the steppes of Tierra del Fuego, Argentina .

Specimens were mounted in Hoyer’s medium, after clearing in Nesbitt’s solution. Material is deposited in the Argentinean Museum of Natural Sciences Bernardino Rivadavia at Buenos Aires, Argentina , in the National Museum of Natural Sciences at Madrid, Spain , and in the private collection of the author.

Abbreviations used: Abd—abdominal segments, AIIIO—sensorial organ of Ant III, Ant—antennal subsegments, PAO— postantennal sense organ, pso— pseudocelli, psp— pseudopores, Th—thoracic segments. MACN—Argentinean Museum of Natural Sciences Bernardino Rivadavia at Buenos Aires, Argentina , MNCN— National Museum of Natural Sciences at Madrid, Spain , JIAP—private collection of the author.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Figs 1–12
and
Table 1
(adults),
Figs 14–19
and
Tables 2–3
(immatures)

Type locality.
Argentina , Tierra del Fuego, near Rio Grande (
53 º 36 ’ S
,
68 º 04’ W
).

Type material.
Holotype female, Tierra de Fuego, near Rio Grande, Argentina ,
Chiliotrichum
dense scrub, with
Festuca gracillima
and
Chiliotrichum diffusum
(after Collantes et al. 1999 ), S.M. Bonaventura and V. Mascitti leg.,
February 2001
. Paratypes : All specimens from same locality as holotype ,
14 females
,
10 males
and
47 juveniles
. Holotype and 10 paratypes deposited in MACN, 10 paratypes in MNCN, and 51 paratypes in JIAP.

Description. Habitus as in
Figs 1–2
. Body length (without antennae) 1.6 mm (female holotype ), 1.3–1.8 mm (female paratypes ), 1.1–1.6 mm (male paratypes ). Body white. Cuticular granulation of whole body relatively uniform, consisting of small secondary granules 1–1.5 mm in diameter, with areas of large ones, especially on head and dorsum of Abd V–VI, where they reach 2–3.5 mm in diameter. Antennal bases and posterior parts of Th II–III and Abd I–V bear bands of dense granulation formed by small granules 0.8–1.5 mm in diameter. Dorsal chaetae well differentiated into meso- and macrochaetae (
Fig. 1
).

Dorsal chaetotaxy as in
Fig. 1
. Th pleurites I, II, III with 2, 3, 3 chaetae respectively. Chaetae s on Th and Abd simple and slightly thickened, similar in shape to ordinary chaetae. Th II and III with basally thickened chaeta s in position m 7 and microsensillum ms adjacent to it. Abd I–IV with chaeta s in position p 3 . One chaeta s also present on Abd II–III as a 7 , on Abd IV–V as p 5 and a pair lateral to genital opening. Full description of dorsal chaetotaxy in
Table 1
. Abd VI with two large, curved anal spines placed on high papillae (
Fig. 6
). Ratio anal spine:claw III as 1.5–1.7 : 1 .

Ventral chaetotaxy as in
Fig. 2
. Head with 3 + 3 postlabial chaetae. Th I–III sterna with 0,1+1, 1+ 1 chaetae respectively. Ventral tube with 4 + 4 distal and 2 + 2 basal chaetae. Abd IV sternum with 1 + 1 psp on furcal area (
Fig. 10
). Abd V sternum with 1 + 1 slightly thickened chaeta s lateral to genital plate. Chaetotaxy of anal lobes as in
Fig. 7
, with 18 chaetae on each ventral anal lobe, chaeta l 2 ’ present.

Description of First instar .
Figs 14–16
represents the sensorial apparatus of Ant III–IV, dorsal chaetotaxy, arrangement of pso and morphology of PAO in first instar larvae.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–5.
Tullbergia rapoporti
sp. nov.
: 1, habitus and dorsal chaetotaxy; 2, habitus and ventral chaetotaxy; 3 – 5, tibiotarsal chaetotaxy and claw of leg I (3), II (4) and III (5). Scales: 0.2 mm (1,2), 0.05 mm (3,4,5).

FIGURES 6–9.
Tullbergia rapoporti
sp. nov.
: 6 –7 , chaetotaxy of Abd V and VI, dorsal (6) and ventral (7); 8 – 9, chaetotaxy of the antenna, dorsal (8) and ventral (9). Scales: 0.1 mm (6,7), 0.05 mm (8,9).

FIGURES 10–14.
Tullbergia rapoporti
sp. nov.
: 10, remnant of furca; 11, chaetotaxy of the labial complex; 12, PAO and antennal pso; 13 – 14, Ant III-IV, Second instar (13), First instar (14). Scales: 0.05 mm (10,11,13), 0.03 mm (12,14).

FIGURES 15–19.
Tullbergia rapoporti
sp. nov.
: 15 – 16, First instar; 15, dorsal chaetotaxy of Th and Abd; 16, PAO; 17 – 19, Second instar; 17, PAO; 18, dorsal chaetotaxy; 19, ventral chaetotaxy of Abd I – VI. Scales: 0.1 mm (15), 0.03 mm (16,17), 0.2 mm (18,19).

TABLE 1.
Tullbergia rapoporti
sp. nov.
Dorsal chaetotaxy of adult animals. Abbreviations: m––mesochaeta; M–macrochaeta; s––chaetae s; ms––microsensillum; AS––anal spines; “–“––denotes absence of chaeta.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Description of Second instar .
Figs 13
and
17–19
represents the sensorial apparatus of Ant III–IV, dorsal chaetotaxy, arrangement of pso and morphology of PAO in second instar larvae. Body length (without antennae) about 0.8 mm . PAO similar to that of adult animals, with about 50 simple vesicles (
Fig. 17
). AIIIO with only two sensory clubs and two minute sensory rods with papillate integumentary fold (the inner sensory club missing). Sensory complex on Ant IV the same as adult animals (
Fig. 13
). Dorsal chaetotaxy reduced, specially the chaetae in m-row (
Fig. 18
and
Table 3
); pso as in adult animals; psp missing (
Figs 18–19
).
Etymology. I dedicate the new species to Professor Eduardo Hugo Rapoport, the eminent Argentinean ecologist and former taxonomist in Collembola .

document.paragraph:
Discussion. The new species is related to Antarctic species of
Tullbergia
with 1,2, 2 pso on Th I–III,
T. crozetensis Deharveng, 1981
,
T. antarctica Lubbock, 1876
and
T. maxima Deharveng, 1981
. Main differences between these species are summarised in
Table 4
. The new species is most similar to
T. crozetensis
. They differ in the empodial appendage (absent in
T. crozetensis
and 0.25–0.50 the length of claw in
T. rapoporti
sp. nov.
), the anal spine:claw III ratio ( 1.35 in
T. crozetensis
and 1.5–1.7 in the new species), the a0 chaeta on Abd VI:anal spine ratio ( 1.1 in
T. crozetensis
and 2 in the new species) and the m0 chaeta on Abd VI:anal spine ratio ( 0.8 in
T. crozetensis
and 1.65 in the new species).

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 2.
Tullbergia rapoporti
sp. nov.
Dorsal chaetotaxy of First instar. Abbreviations: m––mesochaeta; M–macrochaeta; S––macrochaeta s; ms––microsensillum; AS––anal spines; “–“––denotes absence of chaeta.

TABLE 3.
Tullbergia rapoporti
sp. nov.
Dorsal chaetotaxy of Second instar. Abbreviations: m––mesochaeta; M–macrochaeta; s (S)––chaeta (macrochaeta) s; ms––microsensillum; AS––anal spines; “–“––denotes absence of chaeta.

TABLE 4. Main diagnostic characters of
Tullbergia rapoporti
sp. nov.
and related species in the genus
Tullbergia
. (1) PAO—Number of vesicles; (2) AS:Claw—Ratio Anal spine:Claw length; (3) EA:Claw—Ratio empodial appendage:Claw length, r–empodium reduced, 0–empodium absent.

tr.td: r 3–4 Kerguelen Is., Crozet Is., Possesion Is.

heading.emphasis:
Tullbergia meridionalis Cassagnau & Rapoport, 1962
nec Barra ( 1995 )

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material examined. Argentina , Tierra de Fuego, near Rio Grande,
Chiliotrichum
dense scrub, with
Festuca gracillima
and
Chiliotrichum diffusum
(after Collantes et al. 1999 ), S.M. Bonaventura and V. Mascitti leg.,
February 2001, 9
specimens.

Description of specimens from Tierra del Fuego. Habitus as in
Figs 20–21
. Body length (without antennae) 0.50–0.62 mm . Body white. Cuticular granulation of whole body relatively uniform. Antennal bases not marked. Dorsal chaetae well differentiated into meso- and macrochaetae (
Fig. 20
).

Dorsal chaetotaxy as in
Fig. 20
. Th pleurites I, II, III with 2, 3, 3 chaetae respectively. Chaetae s on Th and Abd simple and slightly thickened, similar in form to ordinary chaetae. Th II and III with long, basally thickened chaeta s in position m 7 and microsensillum ms adjacent to it. Abd I–IV with chaeta s in position p 3 . One chaeta s also present on Abd II–III as a 7 , on Abd IV–V as p 5 and a pair lateral to genital opening. Full description of dorsal chaetotaxy is given in
Table 5
Abd VI with two short, curved anal spines placed on papillae. Ratio anal spine:claw III as 0.69–0.72 : 1 .

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 5.
Tullbergia meridionalis
. Dorsal chaetotaxy of adult animals. Abbreviations: m––mesochaeta; M–macrochaeta; s (S)––chaeta (macrochaeta) s; ms––microsensillum; AS––anal spines; “–“––denotes absence of chaeta.

FIGURES 20–21.
Tullbergia meridionalis
: 20, habitus and dorsal chaetotaxy; 21, habitus and ventral chaetotaxy. Scale: 0.1 mm.

FIGURES 22–26.
Tullbergia meridionalis
: 22–23, chaetotaxy of the antenna, dorsal (22) and ventral (23); 24, chaetotaxy of the labial complex; 25, PAO and antennal pso; 26, tibiotarsal chaetotaxy and claw of leg III. Scales: 0.03 mm (22,23), 0.02 mm (24,25,26).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Ventral chaetotaxy as in
Fig. 21
. Head with 3 + 3 postlabial chaetae. Th I–III sterna with 0,1+1, 1+ 1 chaetae respectively. Ventral tube with 4 + 4 distal and 2 + 2 basal chaetae. Abd V sternum with 1 + 1 slightly thickened chaeta s lateral to genital plate.

Remarks. Specimens from Tierra del Fuego conform to the original description by Cassagnau & Rapoport ( 1962 ) from Patagonia ( Argentina ) and differ to the description by Barra ( 1995 ) from Natal , South Africa : number of vesicles in PAO: 20–22 in the specimens from Natal , 36–52 in the specimens from Tierra del Fuego, 30–50 in the types from Patagonia; tibiotarsus III with 14 chaetae in the specimens from Tierra del Fuego, 12 chaetae in the specimens from Natal ; shape of PAO identical in specimens from Tierra del Fuego and Patagonia, different in the specimens from Natal ; position of pso on Abd IV egal in the specimens from Tierra del Fuego and Patagonia,, different in the specimens from Natal ; Ant. IV with sensilla S 7 and S 9 on the same level in the specimens from Tierra del Fuego and Patagonia, on the different level in the specimens from Natal ; shape of guard papillae in AIIIO the same in the specimens from Tierra del Fuego and Patagonia, different in the specimens from Natal . Specimens from Natal are almost certainly a different species, closely related to
T. meridionalis
. The geographical distribution of these species corroborates the idea that southern South America shares a common history with the other austral areas, reflecting the existence of an ancient austral biota (Rapoport 1971 ).

Type locality.
Argentina , Tierra del Fuego, near Rio Grande (
53 º 36 ’ S
,
68 º 04’ W
).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 27–31.
Dinaphorura nerudai
sp. nov.
: 27, habitus and dorsal chaetotaxy; 28, habitus and ventral chaetotaxy; 29, PAO and antennal pso; 30–31, tibiotarsal chaetotaxy and claw of leg I (30) and III (31). Scales: 0.3 mm (27,28), 0.02 mm (29), 0.03 mm (30,31).

FIGURES 32–35.
Dinaphorura nerudai
sp. nov.
: 32, Ant III–IV; 33, chaetotaxy of the labial complex; 34, chaetotaxy of Abd V–VI sternites; 35, chaetotaxy of Abd VI tergite. Scales: 0.03 mm (32,33), 0.05 mm (34,35).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material.
Holotype female, Tierra de Fuego, near Rio Grande, Argentina ,
Chiliotrichum
dense scrub, with
Festuca gracillima
and
Chiliotrichum diffusum
(after Collantes et al. 1999 ), S.M. Bonaventura and V. Mascitti leg.,
February 2001
. Paratypes : All specimens from same locality as holotype ,
44 females
,
23 males
and
46 juveniles
. Holotype and 10 paratypes deposited in MACN, 10 paratypes in MNCN, and 93 paratypes in JIAP.

Dorsal chaetotaxy as in
Fig. 27
. Th pleurites I, II, III with 2, 3, 3 chaetae respectively. Chaetae s on Th and Abd slightly thickened, similar in form to ordinary chaetae. Th II and III with basally thickened chaeta s in position m 7 and microsensillum ms adjacent to it. Abd I–IV with chaeta s in position p 3 . One chaeta s also present on Abd II– III as a 7 , on Abd IV–V as p 5 and a pair lateral to genital opening. Full description of dorsal chaetotaxy is given in
Table 6
. Abd VI with two large, curved anal spines placed on low papillae. Ratio anal spine:claw III as 1–1.25 : 1 . Seven spiniform processes on Abd VI, located as follows: 1 + 1 dorso-medial (dm), 2 + 2 latero-dorsal (ld) and 1 unpaired medio-ventral (mv) (
Fig. 35
).

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 6.
Dinaphorura nerudai
sp. nov.
Dorsal chaetotaxy of adult specimens. Abbreviations: m––mesochaeta; M–macrochaeta; s (S)––chaeta (macrochaeta) s; ms––microsensillum; AS––anal spines; “–“–– denotes absence of chaeta.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Ventral chaetotaxy as in
Fig. 28
. Head with 3 + 3 postlabial chaetae. Th I–III sterna with 0,1+1, 1+ 1 chaetae respectively. Ventral tube with 4 + 4 distal and 2 + 2 basal chaetae. Abd V sternum with 1 + 1 slightly thickened chaeta s lateral to genital plate. Chaetotaxy of anal lobes as in
Fig. 34
.
Etymology. The new species is dedicated to the late Chilean poet Pablo Neruda for his 111 birthday ( July 12, 1904 ).

Discussion. The new species belongs to the group of species with pso formula 11 /011/ 11111 , Abd VI with 7 spiniform processes and elongate PAO,
D. chazeaui Weiner & Najt, 1991
,
D. harrisoni Bagnall, 1948
,
D. laterospina Salmon, 1941
,
D. matileorum Najt, 1988
,
D. pefauri Rubio & Najt, 1979
and
D. spinosissima (Wahlgren, 1906 )
(Table 8 ). They differ in the number of vesicles on PAO (more than 26 vesicles in
D. laterospina
and
D. pefauri
), the apical vesicle on Ant IV (present and conspicuous in
D. laterospina
,
D. pefauri
,
D. harrisoni
and
D. spinosissima
) and the dorsal chaetotaxy (Table 8 ).

Type locality.
Argentina , Tierra del Fuego, near Rio Grande (
53 º 36 ’ S
,
68 º 04’ W
).

Type material.
Holotype female, Tierra de Fuego, near Rio Grande, Argentina ,
Chiliotrichum
dense scrub, with
Festuca gracillima
and
Chiliotrichum diffusum
(after Collantes et al . 1999 ), S.M. Bonaventura and V. Mascitti leg.,
February 2001
. Paratypes : All specimens from same locality as holotype ,
41 females
,
7 males
and
6 juveniles
. Holotype and 10 paratypes deposited in MACN, 10 paratypes in MNCN, and 34 paratypes in JIAP.

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 7.
Dinaphorura najtae
sp. nov.
Dorsal chaetotaxy of adult specimens. Abbreviations: m––mesochaeta; M–macrochaeta; s (S)––chaeta (macrochaeta) s; ms––microsensillum; AS––anal spines; “–“––denotes absence of chaeta.

subSubSection.paragraph:
TABLE 8 .
Main diagnοstic characters οf
Dinaphorura nerudai
sp. nov.
,
Dinaphorura najtae
sp. nov.
and related species in the genus
Dinaphorura
with 11 ⁄011⁄ 11111 dοrsal psο. "?"‾‾denοtes∶ nο data available. ( 1 ) SP-Spinifοrm prοcesses οn Abd vI∶ N‾‾Τοtal number (anal spines nοt included), dm‾‾dοrsοmedial, ld‾‾laterοdοrsal and mv‾‾mediοventral prοcesses, a∶p‾‾Ratiο anteriοr∶pοsteriοr laterοdοrsal prοcesses; ( 2 ) PAΟ-Fοrm, E‾‾elοngate, Τ‾‾triangular, and Number οf vesicles; ( 3 ) Av-Apical vesicle οn Ant Iv, B‾‾bilοbed, S‾‾simple, Τ‾‾trilοbed; ( 4 ) AS ∶C-Ratiο anal spine∶claw length; ( 5 ) Dοrsal chaetοtaxy∶ m, ca, p chaetae series.

subSubSection.paragraph: (*) Abd vI with 2 large curved anal hοrns οn papillae and nine shοrt fat spines after οriginal descriptiοn, but οnly 7 spinifοrm prοcesses are shοwn in the οriginal drawing (Fig. 134 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 36–37.
Dinaphorura najtae
sp. nov.
: habitus and chaetotaxy, dorsal (36) and ventral (37). Scale: 0.2 mm.

FIGURES 38–43.
Dinaphorura najtae
sp. nov.
: 38–39, chaetotaxy of Abd V–VI, ventral (38) and dorsal (39); 40, tibiotarsal chaetotaxy and claw of leg III; 41, chaetotaxy of the labial complex; 42, Ant III–IV; 43, PAO and antennal pso. Scales: 0.04 mm (38,39), 0.02 mm (40,41,42,43).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Dorsal chaetotaxy as in
Fig. 36
. Th pleurites I, II, III with 2, 3, 3 chaetae respectively. Chaetae s on Th and Abd slightly thickened, similar in form to ordinary chaetae. Th II and III with basally thickened chaeta s in position m 7 and microsensillum ms adjacent to it. Abd I–IV with chaeta s in position p 3 . One chaeta s also present on Abd II– III as a 7 , on Abd IV–V as p 5 and a pair lateral to genital opening. Full description of dorsal chaetotaxy is given in
Table 7
. Abd VI with two large, curved anal spines placed on low papillae. Ratio anal spine:claw III as 1–1.17 : 1 . Seven spiniform processes on Abd VI, located as follows: 1 + 1 dorso-medial (dm), 2 + 2 latero-dorsal (ld) and 1 unpaired medio-ventral (mv) (
Fig. 39
).

Ventral chaetotaxy as in
Fig. 37
. Head with 3 + 3 postlabial chaetae. Th I–III sterna with 0,1+1, 1+ 1 chaetae respectively. Ventral tube with 4 + 4 distal and 2 + 2 basal chaetae. Abd V sternum with 1 + 1 slightly thickened chaeta s lateral to genital plate. Chaetotaxy of anal lobes as in
Fig. 38
.
Etymology. The new species is dedicated to the late Judith Najt, a prominent Argentinean researcher of collembolan fauna, who passed away in 2014 .

Discussion. The new species is most similar to
D. americana Rapoport, 1962
and
D. jarai Najt & Rubio, 1978
, they share the pso formula 11 /011/ 11111 and triangular PAO (Table 8 ), but they differ in the number of vesicles on PAO ( 12–15 in
D. americana
, 10-11 in
D. jarai vs
18–20 in the new species), the number of spiniform processes on Abd VI ( 5 in
D. jarai vs
7 in
D. americana
and
D. najtae
sp. nov.
), the apical vesicle on Ant IV (present in
D. jarai
and
D. americana vs
absent in the new species) and the dorsal chaetotaxy (Table 8 ).
